1.title: Wastecooking: Austria

episode of.title: Wastecooking: Kochen was andere verschwenden (TV Series 2015– )

1.plot: David begins his journey from Austria to visit Vienna and Salzburg, and before long, he discovers some very interesting "dirty" little secrets.

2.title: Wastecooking: Germany

episode of.title: Wastecooking: Kochen was andere verschwenden (TV Series 2015– )

2.plot: David visits Germany to demonstrate how the edible urban fruits and wild plants can be part of our diet and deals with a kind of food waste that is often overlooked.

3.title: Wastecooking: The Netherlands

episode of.title: Wastecooking: Kochen was andere verschwenden (TV Series 2015– )

3.plot: As the journey continues in the Netherlands, David gets a taste of the city's snacks and takes a look at the future of nutrition.

4.title: Wastecooking: Belgium

episode of.title: Wastecooking: Kochen was andere verschwenden (TV Series 2015– )

4.plot: In an attempt to reduce kitchen waste, David visits the European Parliament in Belgium, where almost 150kg out of 4000 meals served daily, end up in the bin.

5.title: Wastecooking: France

episode of.title: Wastecooking: Kochen was andere verschwenden (TV Series 2015– )

5.plot: In the fifth and final stop in this amazing waste-cooking journey throughout Europe, David will deal with the matter of the rejected by-catch while contemplating the future of his quest.

imdb.plot outline: According to the UN Food and Agriculture Organization a third of all food produced worldwide is thrown away. In Europe, this is equivalent to 89 tons of groceries per year. How can we stop this waste? Author and cook David Gross conducts a road trip through Austria, Germany, the Netherlands, Belgium and France, cooking exclusively what others throw in the garbage. Easy to spot by his trademark, a mobile stove rebuilt from a dumpster, and his wastemobile which runs exclusively on used cooking oil. Along his way, David Gross meets unconventional top chefs, dedicated food activists, scientists and gourmets. With a great thirst for knowledge, he investigates the causes of food waste and unearths both surprising connections and unexpected solutions. With a healthy dose of humor, David Groß undertakes a road trip trough Europe that calls our everyday consumer lifestyle into question.
imdb.title: Wastecooking: Kochen was andere verschwenden
plot: Journalist and food activist, David Gross, travels through five European countries, on a mission to find a solution to the problem of food loss and waste.::Nick Riganas

According to the UN Food and Agriculture Organization a third of all food produced worldwide is thrown away. In Europe, this is equivalent to 89 tons of groceries per year. How can we stop this waste? Author and cook David Gross conducts a road trip through Austria, Germany, the Netherlands, Belgium and France, cooking exclusively what others throw in the garbage. Easy to spot by his trademark, a mobile stove rebuilt from a dumpster, and his wastemobile which runs exclusively on used cooking oil. Along his way, David Gross meets unconventional top chefs, dedicated food activists, scientists and gourmets. With a great thirst for knowledge, he investigates the causes of food waste and unearths both surprising connections and unexpected solutions. With a healthy dose of humor, David Groß undertakes a road trip trough Europe that calls our everyday consumer lifestyle into question.::David Gross

In search of concrete solutions to the ever-present problem of food loss and food waste, David Gross, journalist and activist, intrepidly sets off on his quest throughout Europe to raise awareness to us, the consumers. With his authentic Wastemobile equipped with an ingenious, custom-made, dumpster stove and always hungry for some used cooking oil, this amazing road trip will begin from Vienna's "dirty" little secrets to continue to Berlin's edible urban fruits and wild plants. From there, David will be off to the Netherlands to take a look into the future of nutrition, and then, he will visit the European Parliament in Belgium where almost 150kg out of 4000 meals served daily end up in the bin. Ultimately, the journey will conclude in Brittany to deal with the matter of the rejected by-catch while the race against food waste continues, underlining the fact that regardless of the nice initiatives, there is still a lot to be done.::Nick Riganas
